Graphical abstract The CO and H2 (syngas) production from methane partial oxidation (MPO) using TiO2 supported Au-Pd bimetallic catalysts are discussed. The supported Au, Pd and Au-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation or co-impregnation method and were characterized. The supported Au-Pd catalyst was selective for reforming and was more active compared to bare TiO2, TiO2 supported Au only, or Pd only catalysts. The catalyst properties before and after MPO reaction were investigated, including the stability of the TiO2 support, and the stability of Au and Pd nanoparticles. The supported Au-Pd catalyst has the highest TON (TONH2 = 23 at 650 °C), compared to supported Au catalyst (TONH2 < 1) and supported Pd catalyst (TONH2 < 1). Based on the analysis of outlet gases from the MPO reaction in a flow reactor, synergetic effects between Au and Pd, where Pd activates CH bonds while gold modulates the behavior of oxygen at the catalyst surface, are shown to contribute to MPO. Additionally, the Au-Pd/TiO2 material shows long-term activity (>12 h) for the MPO reaction at 600 °C. Keywords Methane partial oxidation Syngas Gold-palladium TiO2 bimetallic nanoparticles 1 Introdcution Syngas (a mixture of H2 and CO) is an important precursor for producing liquid hydrocarbon fuels and chemicals in the chemical industry. The production of syngas generally is based on one or more of the following fundamental processes: steam reforming, catalytic partial oxidation, dry reforming, and autothermal reforming (Scheme 1 ) [1,2]. In industrial production, steam reforming of methane is the most widely used method. Catalytic partial oxidation of methane to syngas represents a potential strategy for syngas production [3]. It offers several advantages including low energy requirements, low operational temperature, and the possibility to regulate the H2/CO molar ratio [4,5] Previous studies have shown that reaction conditions can strongly influence the catalytic activity and product distribution of MPO systems. In general, with stoichiometric reactant mixtures (CH4:O2 = 2:1), significantly high temperatures (up to 1200 K) are often required to achieve high conversion and selectivity to partial oxidation products [6]. If the feed stream instead contains a CH4:O2 ratio of 1:2, total oxidation products become favored. Fortunately, H2 and CO become major products in a broad range of ratios higher than 1:2. A variety of reaction equilibria involving methane, oxygen, carbon monoxide, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, water, and surface species such carbon and various oxygenates can exist simultaneously within the reactor, and in this case MPO can occur via an indirect pathway. With long contact times, oxidation reactions dominate in the entrance zone of the reactor, where molecular oxygen is abundant. Downstream from here, steam reforming, dry reforming, and water-gas shift reactions can occur. Further, the exothermic nature of many oxidation pathways can lead to hotspots and heterogeneity within the catalyst bed. The experiments conducted herein therefore focus on relatively low temperature ranges at ambient pressure to favor the production of partial oxidation products, and a rapid flow rate (GHSV = 40,000 h−1) and short packed catalyst bed provides minimal gas residence time and promotes a homogeneous reaction environment. Such conditions favor a direct partial oxidation pathway to CO and H2 and minimize complicating side-reactions. Transition metals from groups 8, 9, and 10 (Ni, Co, Fe, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, Pt) have been reported as active catalysts for methane oxidation [7,8]. Among these metals, nickel based catalysts have been intensively studied as suitable catalysts for methane reforming, due to its relative low cost [9–11]. However, the Ni based materials are easily deactivated by carbon formation and sintering phenomena [12]. The use of noble metals is capable of effectively inhibiting carbon formation during the methane oxidation process. Pt, Pd, Rh, and Ru catalysts have been shown to exhibit better performances than Ni with higher resistances to coke formation [13,14]. In particular, the metal oxide (TiO2, ZrO2, Al2O3 et al.) supported noble metal materials have shown high activity and stability for the partial methane oxidation reaction [15]. Simultaneously, the use of supports significantly decreases the overall cost due to more efficient utilization of catalytic sites of metals. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been widely used as a catalyst support in many studies due to its high chemical and thermal stability. The size and nature of the interaction of a metal nanoparticle with the TiO2 support can strongly influence the catalytic activity and selectivity of the heterogeneous catalystn [16]. The effect of TiO2 supports with different metals (Rh, Ru, Pd, Pt et al.) on the conversion of methane to syngas has been given a great deal of attention [17–19]. TiO2 supported Au and Pd materials have been intensively studied by Hutchings et al., as active catalysts for a variety of reactions such as alcohol oxidation, methane to methanol conversion, organic pollutant decomposition and H2O2 synthesis [20–23]. To the best of our knowledge, the synergistic role of Au, Pd in gas phase methane partial oxidation has not been studied. TiO2 supported Au materials are active catalysts for a wide range of gas phase oxidation reactions such as CO oxidation, olefin epoxidation, and the water-gas shift reaction [24]. In a study of CO oxidation, Stiehl et al. showed that molecular oxygen can be adsorbed on both Au (111) and Au nanoparticles supported on TiO2 [25]. Further, more studies reported the interface of the Au cluster and TiO2 are the active sites for molecularly adsorbed oxygen species [26–29] The excellent oxygen adsorption ability makes TiO2 supported Au materials potential catalysts for partial methane oxidation. TiO2 supported Pd materials are reportedly able to completely oxidized methane at low temperatures (typically below 600 °C) [19,30]. Felvegi et al. had observed the adsorption and dissociation of CH4 on TiO2 supported Pd materials at temperatures as low as 200 °C. Moreover, the production of hydrogen and small amount of methanol was also observed [31]. Recently, Weaver et al. reported the activation of primary CH bonds on PdO (101) [32]. Therefore, by combining the catalytic abilities of Au and Pd nanoparticles on a TiO2 support, it is reasonable to expect a high activity of such a material for methane partial oxidation. Herein, we report a TiO2 supported gold and palladium catalyst (Au-Pd/TiO2) for the partial oxidation of methane to CO and H2. The catalytic activity of Au-Pd/TiO2 was compared with Au/TiO2 and Pd/TiO2 to study the synergetic effect between gold and palladium. The as-synthesized Au-Pd/TiO2 material was able to activate methane at low temperature (>500 °C) and produce H2 and CO with high selectivity. The stability of Au-Pd/TiO2 material was investigated under different temperatures (500–700 °C) and the catalyst was able to maintain activity even after 12 h. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation TiO2 supported Au and Pd nanoparticles were synthesized by the following impregnation method. First, a Au precursor solution was prepared by dissolving 5 g of HAuCl4∙3H2O in 100 mL distilled water. Second, a solution of Pd was prepared by dissolving 0.17 g PdCl2 in 4.15 mL distilled water. Diluted nitric acid was added to the Pd solution to improve solubility. The support (TiO2, Degussa P25) was pretreated with 50 mL, 5% HNO3 for 3 h, followed by washing with a large amount of distilled water and drying in an oven at 80 °C overnight. The Au and Pd solutions were simultaneously added to 3.8 g of pretreated TiO2 while stirring. The obtained homogeneous paste was dried in an oven overnight at 80 °C and then calcined at 400 °C for 3 h to obtain TiO2 supported Au and Pd nanoparticles. The amounts of Au and Pd were calculated as 2.5% for each. The prepared sample is labeled as 5%Au-Pd/TiO2. Other samples containing only one noble metal (5%) were prepared by a similar method. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were performed using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 A) with an operating voltage of 40 kV and a current of 44 mA. Nitrogen (N2) sorption experiments were conducted on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1-1C automated sorption system. The powders were degassed at 150 °C for 6 h prior to the measurements. The surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, and the pore size distributions were calculated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method from the desorption isotherms. Morphological characterization was done using an FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 with an accelerating voltage of 2.0 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed in a PHI model 590 spectrometer with multiprobes (ΦPhysical Electronics Industries Inc.), using Al Kα radiation (λ = 1486.6 eV) operated at 250 W. The shift of binding energy due to relative surface charging was corrected using the C 1s level at 284.6 eV as an internal standard. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were obtained using a JEOL 2010 UHR FasTEM operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples were prepared by dispersing the material in ethanol. A drop of the dispersion was placed on a holey carbon coated copper grid and allowed to dry under ambient conditions. High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) measurements were carried out using a Talos F200X microscope operating at 200 kV equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) detector. Samples for IR spectroscopy were mixed with KBr and pressed at 5 T for 10 s. A Nicolet 8700 FT-IR with MCT detector was used to collect data from 400 to 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 2 cm−1. A blank KBr pellet was used as background and 64 scans were averaged to give the final spectrum. The software suite Specta was used for baseline correction and normalizing the spectra. The zeta (ζ) potential measurements were carried out using a Zetasizer Nano ZS 90 (Malvern Instruments). 2.3 Catalytic activity tests The catalytic activity of each material was evaluated in a continuous flow reactor operating at atmospheric pressure. A 50 mg sample of each material being investigated was packed into a 7 mm inner diameter quartz tube between quartz wool. The reactor tube was housed inside an electrically heated tube furnace connected to a programmable controller. The temperature was ramped at a rate of 10 °C per minute, and a K-type thermocouple positioned near the catalyst bed was used to measure the furnace temperature. A gas mixture consisting of 5% methane and 2.5% oxygen in argon (molar fuel:oxidant ratio of 2:1) was flowed through the catalyst bed at a rate of 50 sccm (GHSV = 40,000 h−1). The composition of the outlet gas stream was analyzed using a MKS e−Vision+ quadrupole mass spectrometer (residual gas analyzer) equipped with a home-built vacuum manifold which allows for the sampling of gas streams at or near atmospheric pressure. The results are reported in terms of methane conversion, mole fractions of reactor outlet species, and turnover numbers with respect to hydrogen and carbon monoxide production. Mass/charge (m/z) signals were standardized by flowing gas mixtures of each individual product and reactant diluted in argon to varying concentrations while maintaining a total flow rate of 50 sccm. Methane conversion represents the overall activity of the material and progression of the methane oxidation reaction, and is defined as the molar flow rates of methane in and out of the catalyst bed: % C H 4 C o n v e r s i o n = m o l C H 4 , i n - m o l C H 4 , o u t m o l C H 4 , i n × 100 Since both total oxidation and partial oxidation products (namely syngas, CO and H2) can be formed, the mole fraction of each measured product is presented as a representation of product selectivity. Further, turnover numbers per minute (TON) are calculated for the desirable products (H2 and CO) generated, based on the amount of noble metal loading in each material: T O N H 2 = m o l H 2 / m i n m o l A u + m o l P d and T O N C O = m o l C O / m i n m o l A u + m o l P d Temperature programmed oxidation was performed using a Netzsch TG 209 F1 Libra thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) coupled to a Netzsch 403 Aëolos quadrupole mass spectrometer. Approximately 20 mg of sample was loaded into an alumina crucible. The sample was soaked in flowing synthetic air (50 sccm) in the TGA chamber for 30 min at a given temperature. The gas was then switched to argon (50 sccm) and the furnace temperature was ramped at a rate of 20 °C/minute to 800 °C. This cycle was repeated at 50 °C intervals. The weight percent of oxygen adsorbed at each temperature was calculated from the desorption curve in the TGA. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 a shows the PXRD patterns of 5% Au-Pd/TiO2 and bare TiO2 samples. Both materials display a mixed-phase (anatase, rutile) nature. With the introduction of Au and Pd nanoparticles, there are three additional diffraction lines appearing at 38.2°, 44.4°, and 64.6°. According to Vegard’s law, the diffraction lines of metal alloy should be in between the two set peaks of the pure metals. [33,34], In Fig. 1b, compared to Au and Pd standard cards (JCPDS No.00-004-0784 and 00-005-0681, respectively), the diffraction lines of 5% Au-Pd/TiO2 could be indexed to Au species. The invisibility of Pd species indicating either Pd has entered into Au crystal lattice, forming Pd-Au core-shell structure, or Pd exists as PdO species which are well dispersed on the surface [35]. Raman spectroscopy was further conducted to investigate PdO species. In Fig. 1c, except for TiO2 vibrational bands, two new bands (star marked) can be observed. The vibrational modes at 442 and 648 cm−1 correspond to Eg and B1g modes of PdO, respectively (Fig. 1d) [36]. In order to study the attraction between nanoparticles (Au, Pd) and active oxide support (TiO2), zeta potentials were measured. Zeta potential is a key indicator of the stability of colloidal dispersions. Table 1 presents the zeta potential results for the bare TiO2, acid pretreated TiO2, and 5%Au-Pd/TiO2, respectively. Acid pretreatment facilitates the dispersion of Au and Pd [23]. The measurements of each sample suspension were carried out immediately after 30 min sonication. The zeta potential of bare TiO2 is 19 ± 5 mV. Although previous studies showed an increased zeta potential along with decreased pH value, we found a slight decrease in zeta potential (15 ± 4 mV) for acid pretreated TiO2. This may be because the material was washed with a large amount of distilled water after the acid pretreatment. When Au and Pd are added to the pretreated TiO2, the composite material exhibits a remarkable increase in zeta potential (30 ± 4 mV), suggesting the positively-charged Au and Pd nanoparticles are dispersed. The incorporation of nanoparticles increased the stability of the TiO2 and the active surface area since particle agglomeration was avoided. Another way to observe the incorporation of metals in TiO2 is to study the morphology. Fig. 2 shows typical scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the bare TiO2 (Fig. 2a) and as-synthesized TiO2 supported Au and Pd nanoparticles (Fig. 2b). The observed particle size of bare TiO2 agrees with the commercial data which has an average particle size of about 20–30 nm [37]. After Au and Pd were incorporated, in Fig. 2b, no obvious morphology or particle size change can be observed, which indicates the successful deposition of well dispersed Au and Pd nanoparticles on the TiO2 surface. No obvious metal agglomerates or clusters are observed. The deposition of Au and Pd was further characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fig. 2c shows the high crystallinity of the TiO2 support particles. The measured d-spacing is 0.35 nm, which is assigned to the (101) plane of anatase. The 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample has an average particle size between 20–40 nm, which can be observed in Fig. 2d. Moreover, the small metal nanoparticles (Au, Pd) are well dispersed on the surface of TiO2 support. Fig. 2e suggests that the metal nanoparticles (circled in white) have an average particle size around 3 nm. The deposition of Au and Pd was further investigated by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and high-angle angular dark field (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM). First EDS was conducted to determine the composition of the small particles dispersed on the surface of TiO2. In Fig. 3 a, both Au and Pd could be observed from EDS with atomic percentages of 2.5% and 1.5%, respectively. This composition is in accordance with the experimental percentage (2.5% each). These STEM and the element mapping results show that Au and Pd nanoparticles were successfully dispersed on the TiO2 support. The element composition of a single particle was investigated. In Fig. 3b–e, HAADF-STEM results for 5%Au-Pd/TiO2, Au and Pd atoms are fabricated uniformly over the entire nanoparticle. The presence of Au and Pd species can be further shown by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). In Fig. 4 a, the two spin-orbit components Pd 3d5/2 (345 eV) and Pd 3d3/2 (340 eV) are separated by 5 eV [38,39]. However, these two energy levels are much higher than typical values. According to the literature, generally the highest Pd 3d5/2 (339.4 eV) is attributed to PdO2, the component at around 336.5 eV is due to PdO, and the Pd° signal is present at 335 eV [40]. The much higher value of Pd 3d in this study is highly affected by several factors, including the presence of Au, calcination process, and the metal support [41] Hutchings et al. observed the same high value of Pd 3d on an Al2O3 support. The oxidation state was assigned to PdO.[42]. Moreover, the oxidation of Pd occurs as low as 200 °C [43] The preparation temperature in this study was 400 °C, and from a thermodynamic view, is high enough for the formation of PdO. More importantly, PdO shown in XPS data is consistent with Raman spectroscopy in Fig. 1c, d. The peak at 336 eV was assigned to Au 4d. Generally, Au 4d located around 335 eV depends on the metal support [44]. However, in this study, spectral contributions from both Pd and Au, lead to severe overlap of peaks. The analysis of the Au 4d transition alone is not sufficient. As for the oxidation state of Au, Au 4f is the most widely studied spin-orbit component. In Fig. 4b, the peaks at 87.5 eV and 84.0 eV can be assigned to Au 4f 5/2 and Au 4f 7/2, respectively. Both of these two peaks belong to Au° [45]. The metallic state of Au in XPS is in excellent agreement with XRD results. 3.2 Catalytic activity of methane partial oxidation The activity of 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 material was tested for methane partial oxidation (MPO). As a comparison, 5%Au/TiO2, 5%Pd/TiO2 and bare TiO2 were also tested under identical conditions. Methane conversion values are shown in Fig. 5 . Abrupt onset of activity is observed for both the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 and 5%Pd/TiO2 materials at 475 °C, with 5%Pd/TiO2 yielding somewhat higher conversion initially. The 5%Au/TiO2 and the unmodified TiO2 are significantly less active, yielding minimal methane conversion below 625 °C. The 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample exhibits the highest overall activity which increases to a maximum of 33% conversion at 650 °C and then decreases again at higher temperatures. Compared to the thermodynamic equilibrium, the methane conversion is about 50% (at 873 K, 1 bar) using CH4/O2 = 2:1 ratio [46]. The difference between reaction conversion and equilibrium conversion may due to the deactivation of the catalyst at high temperature, which leads to limited activity. The deactivation involves phase transformation of support (anatase to rutile), metal agglomeration (Au, Pd), surface sintering, coke deposition, formation of Pd(OH)2 and pore blockage [47,48]. Each of these factors would restrain the catalyst from maximum conversion activity (reaching the thermodynamic equilibrium limit). The 5%Pd/TiO2 sample is somewhat more active than 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 in the lower temperature range of 475–525 °C, reaching a maximum conversion of 25% conversion at 525 °C. However, the activity of 5%Pd/TiO2 decreases above this temperature, and only recovers at 750 °C and higher. The control material yields a maximum of 25% conversion at 800 °C. Gold alone appears to have a deactivating effect in the 5%Au/TiO2 material, which only achieves a maximum of 17% methane conversion at 800 °C. Overall methane conversion, however, is not fully descriptive of the reaction pathway. Therefore, the composition of the outlet gas stream is presented in Fig. 6 in terms of mole fraction (χ) of the reactants methane and oxygen, and the products hydrogen, carbon monoxide, and carbon dioxide. During the testing of each material, a minimal amount of water was also detected in the mass spectrum, but desorption of water from the catalyst occurred so slowly that quantification was not possible. The generation of synthesis gas (CO and H2) is heavily favored on the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6a). Oxygen becomes a limiting reactant in this system at 500 °C and at temperatures 575 °C and higher, CO formation becomes favorable over CO2. At low temperatures, a significant amount of total oxidation products as well as partial oxidation products are observed. However, when peak activity is achieved at 675 °C, the generation of CO2 is minimal (χCO2 = 0.043), and hydrogen and carbon monoxide are more prolifically produced (χH2 = 0.63 and χCO = 0.16). By comparison, the 5%Au/TiO2 material is completely ineffective for the production of syngas (Fig. 6b). Methane is poorly activated over the entire temperature range studied with 5%Au/TiO2 and the only significant product detected is carbon dioxide. The 5%Pd/TiO2 sample shows a similar level of overall methane conversion activity to the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 material and oxygen also becomes a limiting reactant at 525 °C in this system (Fig. 6c). However, the production of CO2 is far more favorable and is detected in the outlet gas in a much higher concentration than both H2 and CO over the entire temperature range. Above 675 °C, the production of hydrogen and carbon dioxide increases, but is still comparatively dominated by CO2 generation. The unmodified TiO2 support favors the production of hydrogen and carbon monoxide over carbon dioxide, but the overall conversion is poor (Fig. 6d). Interestingly, the control system is more active and promotes a more desirable product distribution than the 5%Au/TiO2 catalyst, indicating Au is inactive for CH bond activation. The presence of Pd in the catalyst appears to be necessary for effective methane activation, while the combination of both Au and Pd is required to promote selectivity toward synthesis gas. To further illustrate this effect, turnover numbers (TON) for the synthesis gas products are presented in Fig. 8e–f. Not only is the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 system catalytic with respect to methane conversion (TON >1), but the production of desirable partial oxidation products (TONH2 Fig. 8e, and TONCO Fig. 8f) is highly favorable. 3.3 Stability tests of TiO2 supported Au-Pd catalysts In addition to catalytic efficiency, catalyst stability is an important evaluation. Around 650 °C, 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 has the highest conversion (Fig. 5). Understanding the changes to the catalyst at this temperature would be meaningful. Therefore, the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 catalyst was collected after MPO reaction at 650 °C, and then investigated by elemental mapping by EDS. In Fig. 7 a, the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample after MPO suggests a much different elemental composition than before MPO (Fig. 4). The atomic percentage of Au increases to 16% after MPO. The significant increase of Au component is due to a transformation of small Au nanoparticles (3 nm) to larger Au clusters (100 nm). This agglomeration could be observed by elemental mapping (Fig. 7c). In contrast, the composition of Pd was preserved with an atomic percentage of 3% (Fig. 7a), which indicates a better stability of Pd compared to Au under high temperature oxidizing conditions. However, a slight agglomeration of Pd nanoparticles was still detected (Fig. 7f). During the high temperature oxidation conditions, Au atoms and Pd atoms aggregated. The aggregation of nanoparticles to clusters indicates instability of Au and Pd nanoparticles at the operating MPO reaction temperature (550 °C). It has been determined previously that above 500 °C, the Au-Pd alloy nanoparticles cannot be preserved [41]. The segregation of Pd and Au and their agglomeration is believed to be triggered by the high temperature, rather than the methane-rich environment. To confirm this, we calcined the 5% Au-Pd/TiO2 sample under air at 650 °C, and the same agglomeration behavior was observed (Fig. S2). Additionally, XRD, IR spectroscopy, Raman Spectroscopy, SEM, EDS mapping, and N2 sorption techniques were also applied to study the catalyst after MPO. Fig. S3a displays the change of crystal structures of 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 before and after MPO reaction. No additional diffraction lines were observed, and 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 maintained the anatase/rutile mixed phase, which indicates the excellent structural stability of the TiO2 support. In addition, the diffraction lines that correspond to Au are still present after MPO. This comparison before and after MPO was further explored by IR spectroscopy (Fig. S3b). The as-prepared sample shows a vibration at 3500 cm−1 which correlates with absorbed hydroxyl or water on the surface of the TiO2 [49]. The peak at 1635 cm−1 corresponds to the asymmetric stretch of titanium carboxylate. The bands between 800 cm−1 and 450 cm−1 correspond to the vibrational modes of TiO2. The shoulder around 1100 cm−1 is possibly from Au-TiO2 and Pd-TiO2 interactions [50]. Such interactions may explain the dramatic reduction in this shoulder following exposure to the MPO reaction, since sintering of the Au, Pd co-catalysts could result in a lower energy distribution. The B1g mode in Figure S3c suggests that the PdO species are preserved after the MPO reaction. The aggregation of nanoparticles may lead to a smaller surface area. Therefore, the surface area of 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 was examined. Before MPO reaction, 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample possessed a surface area of 72 m2/g (Fig. S5a). However, following the MPO reaction, the surface area decreased to 43 m2/g (Fig. S5b). The pores of the catalyst may be blocked by sintered metals. The decrease of pore volume can be observed in Fig. S5. The largest pore volume decreased from 370 cc/g to 170 cc/g after the MPO reaction. In addition, according to the XRD and IR results, the TiO2 support maintained its structure. The decrease of the surface area can be ascribed to the agglomeration of Au, Pd nanoparticles and the pore blockage following the MPO reaction. Au and Pd nanoparticles (≈3 nm) started to sinter and form nanoclusters (≈100 nm) when the reaction temperature exceeded 500 °C. To test whether the MPO activity of the catalyst would be significantly affected by nanoparticle agglomeration, time-dependent behavior of the MPO reaction was explored (Fig. 8). Methane conversion was studied at a fixed temperature (600 °C). Fig. 8a shows that under steady-state conditions, the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 catalyst was able to preserve most of the initial methane oxidation activity. The catalyst exhibited the highest initial conversion of 41%, and the conversion remained above 27% over the course of 12 h. The product distribution over this period is displayed in Fig. 8b. The desirable MPO products, hydrogen and carbon monoxide, were observed as major products during the whole stability test. Therefore, the long-term stability and high temperature stability of the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 catalyst strongly suggest that the MPO activity is not limited by the size (up to 100 nm) of Au and Pd. Despite the observed agglomeration of nanoparticles to nanoclusters, methane oxidation to syngas was still achieved. 4 Discussion 4.1 Roles of Pd and Au in MPO reaction The ability of the catalysts to dissociate CH bonds and adsorb oxygen species are important factors that influence the efficiency of syngas production [51]. By comparing the efficiencies of the different catalysts (5%Au-Pd/TiO2, 5%Au/TiO2, 5%Pd/TiO2, TiO2) prepared in this study, good methane conversion, and CO, H2 selectivity can be achieved only by using Au and Pd simultaneously. Based on the methane conversion results (Fig. 5), pure TiO2 and 5%Au/TiO2 barely have any conversion around 500 °C. However, 5%Pd/TiO2 has even higher conversion than 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 at 520 °C, indicating that Pd is the critical factor that promotes the dissociation of the CH bonds. Similar performance can be found in other studies [52,53]. Additionally, in Fig. 6c, by using 5%Pd/TiO2, the catalyst is able to decompose methane and consume oxygen around 500 °C to produce CO2 and H2, which further manifests the methane activation ability of Pd particles. While the material containing only Pd exhibits high methane conversion, the total oxidation products obtained are of little value. The role of Au, as reported in the literature, involves the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen molecules. Thus, the oxygen adsorption ability of all the catalysts was investigated. In Fig. S6, the 5%Au/TiO2 sample shows the highest amount of oxygen adsorption, indicating Au contributes more to oxygen adsorption than Pd in MPO reaction. Moreover, according to the analysis of the outlet gases over 5%Au/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6b), the consumption of oxygen increases as does the formation of COx (CO or CO2), demonstrating that Au particles are able to facilitate the adsorption and dissociation of oxygen for subsequent oxidation of surface carbonaceous species. 4.2 Methane partial oxidation reaction pathways and mechanism over Au-Pd/TiO2 material The catalytic mechanisms of the MPO reaction are different based on various catalysts [7,54]. The main divergence is whether the primary carbonaceous product is CO or CO2. Direct reaction pathway: (5) C H 4 → C H x + 2 - 0.5 x H 2 → + 0.5 O 2 C O + 2 H 2 Indirect reaction pathway: (6) C H 4 → + 0.5 O 2 C O 2 + H 2 O → + u n t r e a t e d C H 4 C O + H 2 In the direct mechanism (Eq. (5)), CO is produced from the reaction of adsorbed oxygen with carbonaceous species formed from methane decomposition. In the indirect mechanism (Eq. (6)), the combustion of methane first yields steam and CO2, followed by reaction with excess methane to form CO and H2 [55]. Due to the significantly slower kinetics of the indirect mechanism, this reaction usually requires much longer contact times between catalyst and gas to form products compared to the direct mechanism. In this supported Au-Pd system, the direct reaction pathway is believed to be the dominant reaction. Under conditions where H2 and CO are the dominant product, CO2 and H2O are only detected in low amounts. We believe that the short contact time in the packed bed is critical for favoring the direct MPO path. Taking into account the above observations from the literature and our experimental data, the reaction pathway of methane partial oxidation over Au-Pd/TiO2 material is proposed (Scheme 2 ). Under stoichiometric conditions and temperatures above 300 °C, the oxygen in the PdO is stable and unlikely to be extracted [56]. This low concentration of extractable lattice oxygen is necessary for the selective production of CO and H2. If these oxygen species were more labile, CO2 and H2O would be the preferred products. In this case, CH4 is dissociatively chemisorbed on PdO sites to form surface adsorbed CH* 4-x and H* species (Scheme 2, process . The CH* 4-x species ultimately dissociate to C* species (surface adsorbed carbon, process and the H* species can then easily desorb as H2 molecules (process [57]. The surface adsorbed oxygen species O* which are generated from the O2 molecules adsorb and dissociate on Au sites (process could further oxidize C* species to CO (process . Based on our IR results (Fig. S3), this is likely to occur via a carboxylate intermediate. Several surface oxygen species such as O2 −, O−, O2 2- should be considered as intermediates during the dissociation of oxygen molecules. There is also a possibility to form CH3OH or CH3OOH or CH3OO*, but at the experimental temperature range used, the produced CH3OH would be quickly decomposed to HCHO or COx and finally transform to CO and H2. 4.3 The critical factors for methane partial oxidation activity Based on the proposed mechanism, several factors affecting the catalytic activity need to be studied. First, the formation of H2O is known to strongly inhibit methane oxidation rates due to the formation of Pd(OH)2 [47]. Compared to H2, the water molecules desorb from the catalyst surface slowly, inhibit the migration of surface oxygen species and block of active sites [58]. Without the regeneration of active sites, the partial oxidation rate decreases. Another possible factor that may affect catalytic activity is the sintering of metal nanoparticles at high temperature. The effects of cluster size has been reported as a critical feature for the Ir catalyzed methane oxidation system. The reactivity of these clusters increases with increasing dispersion [59]. However, in Pd catalyzed methane oxidation systems, the decreased dispersion of palladium does not lead to a decreased reaction rate. Iglesia et al. reported that CH bond activation rate constants did not vary with Pd dispersion [60]. Moreover, Briot and Primet observed that larger PdO clusters (agglomerated Pd small particles) give higher CH4 oxidation rates than smaller PdO particles when using a PdO/Al2O3 catalyst at 600 °C [61]. The higher activity of agglomerated PdO clusters is consistent with our results from the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample. As mentioned above, the aggregation of Au, Pd particles of 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 occurs around 550 °C and beyond this temperature, the cluster sizes keep increasing. The bigger cluster sizes PdO may lead to a higher methane conversion up to 675 °C (Fig. 5). Above 675 °C, the methane conversion started to decrease, which may be attributed to several factors including Au sintering, carbon deposition, and decrease of surface area. Compared to Pd, Au is more sensitive to size. For instance, the O2 adsorption ability of Au nanoparticles is affected by size in some oxidizing reactions (e.g. CO oxidation), due to the catalytic inactivity of large Au particles [62,63]. Decreasing the oxygen dissociation rate also led to carbon deposition. When the oxygen dissociation rate on Au cluster surfaces is slow, excess C* species form carbon instead of being oxidized to CO [64]. The undesirable carbon deposition may lead to blocking of active sites and further decrease the reaction rate. Carbon formation can be observed via the comparison of TEM images before (Fig. 3b) and after (Fig. S4) MPO reactions over the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample. Moreover, the TGA data (Figure S8) suggest that there is a slight weight loss from 150 °C to 350 °C of the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 after the MPO sample, indicating the formation of carbon during the MPO reaction. 5 Conclusion Herein we have described the preparation and application of a TiO2 supported Au-Pd catalyst for the methane partial oxidation to syngas. Methane conversion to syngas activity begins and increases rapidly above 500 °C, reaching a peak (33%) at 650 °C, at which point the selectivity toward H2 and CO is most favorable over total oxidation products. A series of investigations of methane conversion, outlet gas composition, and the calculation of turnover number were made. The 5%Au/TiO2 sample shows poor ability of methane conversion and the 5%Pd/TiO2 sample shows poor syngas selectivity. Good methane conversion and CO/H2 selectivity can only be achieved using the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample. We believe there is a synergistic relationship between Au and Pd and this is the key factor for the MPO activity, where Pd is effective in activating the C–H bonds in methane while gold plays a role in modulating the behavior of oxygen at the catalyst surface. In addition, for the stability test, methane conversion (>27%) using the 5%Au-Pd/TiO2 sample can be preserved at 600 °C for more than 12 h. For future studies, various alloyed structures (such as core-shell structure), metal dispersion, and different Au/Pd ratios will be important to further understand and optimize such systems. coredata.dc:description: The CO and H2 (syngas) production from methane partial oxidation (MPO) using TiO2 supported Au-Pd bimetallic catalysts are discussed. The supported Au, Pd and Au-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation or co-impregnation method and were characterized. The supported Au-Pd catalyst was selective for reforming and was more active compared to bare TiO2, TiO2 supported Au only, or Pd only catalysts. The catalyst properties before and after MPO reaction were investigated, including the stability of the TiO2 support, and the stability of Au and Pd nanoparticles. The supported Au-Pd catalyst has the highest TON (TONH2 = 23 at 650 °C), compared to supported Au catalyst (TONH2 < 1) and supported Pd catalyst (TONH2 < 1). Based on the analysis of outlet gases from the MPO reaction in a flow reactor, synergetic effects between Au and Pd, where Pd activates CH bonds while gold modulates the behavior of oxygen at the catalyst surface, are shown to contribute to MPO. Additionally, the Au-Pd/TiO2 material shows long-term activity (>12 h) for the MPO reaction at 600 °C.
coredata.dc:title: TiO2 Supported gold–palladium catalyst for effective syngas production from methane partial oxidation
